Problem:
Suppose there is a function \\(z(x, t)\\) governed by the partial differential equation (PDE) \\(\\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial t} + x \\frac{\\partial z}{\\partial x} = 0\\) where x represents space and t represents time. An intervention \\(h(x, t)\\) is defined as \\(z(x, t) = u(x, t) + v(x, t)\\), with \\(u(x, t)\\) and \\(v(x, t)\\) being solutions to another set of PDEs.

If an intervention modifies the function as \\(z(x, t) = u(x, t) - v(x, t)\\) at time \\(t = t_1\\), will the resultant state at time \\(T > t_1\\) directly follow from the transformation applied at \\(t_1\\)?
Explanation: After the intervention, the new form of the function explicitly dictates its future evolution. Given the PDE's linear nature and lack of additional independent variables or non-linear terms, the subsequent state at any time \\(T\\) can be inferred directly from the state at the time of intervention \\(t_1\\).
